S0.T1.caption: Table 1. Comparing CCB with ranking and slate regarding their action spaces and reward observations.
references: Related work.Combinatorial bandits to choose a subset in the action space to maximize the reward has been studied much in the online learning literature (Chen et al., 2013; Qin et al., 2014), but there is no existing work discussing OPE/L in this setup thus far. Ranking OPE  (Chen et al., 2013; Qin et al., 2014), but there is no existing work discussing OPE/L in this setup thus far. Ranking OPE (Li et al., 2018; McInerney et al., 2020; Kiyohara et al., 2022, 2023) and slate OPE  (Li et al., 2018; McInerney et al., 2020; Kiyohara et al., 2022, 2023) and slate OPE (Swaminathan and Joachims, 2015a; Vlassis et al., 2021; Kiyohara et al., 2024b) study similar types of OPE/L problems. However, as shown in Table  (Swaminathan and Joachims, 2015a; Vlassis et al., 2021; Kiyohara et al., 2024b) study similar types of OPE/L problems. However, as shown in Table 1, the problem of CCB differs from both regarding the form of the action space. First, the ranking setup considers evaluating a ranking policy that aims to optimize the ranking of a given action space 𝒜 𝒜 \mathcal{A} caligraphic_A , and in the logged data, the rewards corresponding to each position in the ranking are observable, which is unavailable in CCB. Thus, estimators developed for the ranking setup  𝒜 𝒜 \mathcal{A} caligraphic_A 𝒜 𝒜 𝒜 𝒜 𝒜\mathcal{A} \mathcal{A}caligraphic_A caligraphic_A, and in the logged data, the rewards corresponding to each position in the ranking are observable, which is unavailable in CCB. Thus, estimators developed for the ranking setup (Li et al., 2018; McInerney et al., 2020; Kiyohara et al., 2022, 2023) cannot be applied to solve OPE/L in CCB. Second, the slate setup considers choosing (Li et al., 2018; McInerney et al., 2020; Kiyohara et al., 2022, 2023) cannot be applied to solve OPE/L in CCB.
